1oHN BANCROFT, having removed from


~ Brandywine Bridge, to Providence Facto-
ry, Delaware Go. Pa, takes this means to in
form his friends and the public generally, that
he there continues the Careling of Wool, for all
those who are pleased to favor him with their
custom; ard that he hopes by strict attention and
punctuality, to merit continuance OF pub
lie patronage. He also takes this opportunity
to inform those to whose favor he was indebted
for work in this line, while at Brandywine Bridge,
that all wool left for him to card John Torberts
Store, or at the soap Factory of Branton s Ban.
croft, Wilmington, or at VIM M'Cauley's Store,
Brandy zine, will be taken from thence once ev
cry week, and, being carded, will be punctually
rctuned the week following; hoping, by the a
bove arrangement, and punctually in the return
and good performance of the work conided tt
him, they may be induced TO continue their ia
yours.

AN ORDlNA ANCE for the regulation OF the own


eIs riders, and drivers of carriages, wagons,


carts, drays, and horses, within the Borough OF


Wilmington.


SEC /. BE It ordatnedby Me Burgesses and b.
rough Council Of the Borough Of lpiioington,
That from and after the passing oftbls ordinance,
all and every the drivers or driver OF all stages,
coaches. wagons, carts, drays, and other car
riages of pleasure or burthcn, driving and passing
in and through the streets, lanes, or alley OF tins
Borough, shall keep on that side Of the street,
lane or alley oil his or their right handy, respect
iyely, in the passing directions and if any driver
OF any such carriage, wagon, cart or dray, shall
drive the same III the middle of the street, lane
or alley, or on the left hand side ii the same, 50
as to prevent or obstruct another carriage from
passing along said street, every driver SO offend
ing shall forfeit and pay for every such offence,
sum not exceeding five dollarJ nor less than one
dollar, to be recovered with COSTS before either
of the iiurgesses, in the same manner as debts
under forty shllngs are by law recoverable, one
moety whereof shall be for the use of the person
suing for the same, and tie other muictv Shall be
for the use of the Borough.


SEC. . Ind be 1t further ord,Haed, That if
any driver Of any such carriage, or If any person
riding upon any horse, mare or geiding, shall per
INIT suffer the beast or beasts he shall so drive
| or ride, to so in gallop or other immoderate
gait, or shall engage in running or racing in any
manner, with the driver rider of any other car
riage, horse, mare or geldng, within any of the
streets, lanes or alleys Of tins Borough, every
person offending, shall forfeit and pay for eve
ry such offence, sum not exceeding Five dol
lars nor less than one dollar, to be recovered
with costs, by any person, in the manner and IL,
the uses herein before mentioned.


SEC ;. Ind be L further mdaincd, That if an,
person shall wiltully permit or suffer any horse
mare or geldng TO go at large through any 0
the streets, lanes or ALLEYS, ofthis borough, ever,
person SO offending shall forfeit and pay for eve
ny such offence, the sum Of one dollar, to be re
covered with costs, by any person, in the man
ner and for the uses herein before mentioned.
SEC. 4. Ind be II further oedaiaea, That TIL
e Ordinance entitled can Ordinance to prevcn
the accidents and dangers that may happen b
peoples driving their teams out Of walk taste
than is herein specified, and persons playing a
long bullets or any other game whereby thcr
may be damage sustained" passed on the thirty
first day of August in the year Of our LORD on
: thousand seven hundred and tifty-onc, be, an
the same thereby repealed, made null and void
: Passed at the Town lIall--April Z, 1927.
JAMES BR0BSoN, First Burgess.

To THE EDIToRs.-In the Intelligencer
ct this morning, read an account OF the loss
Of number of sheep about Waterville, in
the State of New-York, which as stated, was
occasioned by the grub worm making its
Judgement above the eye of sheep. and that
no means as yet had been discovered for its
destruction.


Sheep being esteemed valuable stock,
anc the growers of wool valuable class Of
citizens, disease so destructive to that use
full animal is worthy of notice; and as deem
it duty incumbent upon every citizen to
furnish such information, when in his pos
session, as may conduce to the public good,
for the benefit of those interested, will
state what know to be a fact. The oil q
amber which may be had at most OF the a.
pothecary shops, will instantly dislodge all
worms, maggots, &c. 1t may be applied by
dipping feather into the amber, and gently
stroking the parts affected. This remedy
has proved effectual when every other ap-
plication has been used in vain. Should this
remedy succeed with sheep, as when appli-
ed to all other animals, it will be a source OF
much qualification to--yours, respectfully


GEO. JOHNSON.

FH SlChlNG FoOL ny.


During the winter months, poultry Of all
kinds, if tolerably fed, are apt to become We
ry fat; and it is during this period that eggs
are scarcest, and OF course dearest.-To
remedy this in some measure, several farm
ers' wives in this neighborhood, are actually
in the habit of physicing their chuckies and
the practice is said to have wonderful ct
feet in restoring their suspended laying pow
ers. The recipe is exceedingly cheap and
simple, and may be recorded here for the
benefit of hem wives in other quarters. Di-
Lutte and mix two ounces of glauber salts in
dish of cold porridge, or any other food,
and scatter the same we'll aboutthe poultry
yard, SO that no bird may eat too much; and
afthe effects are not apparent in two or three
days, repeat the dose at intervals, till the
accumulation of eggs indicate that you have
gone far enough. On farm not many miles
from this, town, the family complained that
although they had dozens of lazy hens they
could not get single egg to breakfast. and
this circumstance reminded one of the
daughters of the necessity of having recourse
to her wanted charm. To work therefore
she set, to the great annoyance of an Eng
lish dairy-maid, who averred that also sh'
had hundreds of poultry under her charge
she never before heard of such thing, ant
shat she was sure the birds would all de-
Miss ----, however, persevered, and in tn
course of a very few days, Easther found sew
eral eggs, and from that moment declare
herself firm convert to the improved meth
cd of managing poultry.

AT WILMINGlON, DCLVARE.


Under the superintendent and etruction of
WILLIAM SHERER, assisted by aomplished
female teachers. Il


The course of instruction pursued aAis SEM
mary, comprises all the useful, and mt of the
ornamental branches of female education The
daily exercises are Orthography, Reading,Wrt-
ing, Arithmetic, English Grammar, Rh.,ric;
Geography and History, ancient and MORN,
with constant reference to the best maps nd I
charts; Construction of maps; use Of the Globt
Natural History; Natural Philosophy, ncludin,
Astronomy and Chemistry Elements Of Moral
Science.


Ueekip Exercises. biblical Recitations; Evil
dences Of Christianity, Letter Writing, and 9th.
er species of Compositions Recapitulatlons,


1,rms-Board and tuition, in any Of the tori;
going branches, s32, so per quarter; or, If palo
in advance, $50, Music, including the use OF
piano, s12, French, by one of the best masters,
Sc per quarter. Moderate extra charges foi
Drawing and other ornamental branches.


The discipline of tho school is mild, parental
and christian Particular attention is paid mol
only to the manners Of the young ladies, but tt
their moral md religious instruction. They arc
regularly conducted to such places OF worship
and Sunday Schools, as their parents and guar
dians approve. Exercise and recreation, being
esSehtli 10 ule Preservaeioh vi heai.n anu
mental energy, occupy the intervals Of time no
devoted to study. The institution, III all its de
partmcnts, is conducted in a manner which !
is hoped, will meet the entire appreciation OF it
patrons.

Red Petter.-It should be transplanted
into beds, where it is togrow, the last week
in May, 1t should be put in rows, two feet
apart, and the plants sixteen inches from
each other, in good rich garden mould, well
mellowed. The plants should be prepared
for transplanting by sowing the seed in hot
bed, placed in a small box, and covering it
one fourth of an inch deep, about the last
week in April. This hot bed is made by
laying twelve inches of new horse dung in
the bottom of the box, and covering it with
six inches of good garden mould. II any
freezing or very cold weather should hap
pen after the plants come up, let the box be
covered with board until the weather
changes.


1t should be hoed as often, and in the
same manner as cabbage. The pods or
capsules must be picked off and strung up in
a garnet, or other dry room, about the last
of September, or, at any rate, before the tall
frosts.


Savo,y.-It should be sowed about the
first of May, in rows eighteen inches apart,
and treated nearly like onions. Hyssop and
thyme may be treated In the same manner


Sare-It should be sowed in a small bed,
the first day Of MAY, and be transplanted
where it is to grow, when the plants are one
year old The ground should be somewhat





dry, and well manured.


Oyster Plant-The salsafy, or oyster
plant, is vegetable of easy production. and
universally eaten, when introduced to the
table. 1t resembles small parsnip in its
appearance. 1t is raised annually from
seeds, requiring no more care than the car
rot. 1t bears a tolerablc crop In Europe
it is eaten both boiled and fried. In this
country it is parboiled, and then fried either
in butter or without. In its taste, It SC
strongly resembles the oyster, that wher
sliced, and fried in butter, it can scarcely b'
distinguished from it. II is in eating iron
November to May. Like the parsnip it viii
stand out the whole winter


Cress.--Cress, or Pepper Grass, is yer,
good in salads along with lecture and white
mustard. 1t should be sown in drills, prett,
thick (as should the white mustard) and Gu
young A small quantity, IN the salad
son, should be sown every ten days, ant
slightly covered.

Extract Of a letter t,um Rer. EJenesa Harris.
am pleased With this opportunity of relating
a few facts which may serve in commendation OF
your excellent Cough Drops. For ten years I
was afflicted with pulmonary complaint, my
cough was severe, my appetite weak, and
strength failing. | used many popular medi-
cines, but only found temporary relief, until by
continued use ofyour valuable Drops, have
been blessed with such perfect health as to rem
! der further means unnecessary.


EBENEZER HARRIS.
4 Salem, " T.. Jan 10, 1925.


0iessrs. Crosby'S.-I have for IS years been
troubled with an affection ofthe breast and lungs
attended with severe cough, pain in the side
and difficulty Of breathing; and in the fall of1S25
l became SO much reduced that my life was des
paired of and receiving no visible benefit from
my physician, | was advised to make trial of Ii
Motifs Cough Drops, and after taking one bottle
was restored to perfect health; and it is my firm
belief, that the use Of the above named drops
saved my life, THOMAS JONES.

full articles.headline: WOOL CARDING.
full articles.article:
1oHN BANCROFT, having removed from


~ Brandywine Bridge, to Providence Facto-
ry, Delaware Go. Pa, takes this means to in
form his friends and the public generally, that
he there continues the Careling of Wool, for all
those who are pleased to favor him with their
custom; ard that he hopes by strict attention and
punctuality, to merit continuance OF pub
lie patronage. He also takes this opportunity
to inform those to whose favor he was indebted
for work in this line, while at Brandywine Bridge,
that all wool left for him to card John Torberts
Store, or at the soap Factory of Branton s Ban.
croft, Wilmington, or at VIM M'Cauley's Store,
Brandy zine, will be taken from thence once ev
cry week, and, being carded, will be punctually
rctuned the week following; hoping, by the a
bove arrangement, and punctually in the return
and good performance of the work conided tt
him, they may be induced TO continue their ia
yours.


4lh mo- S, 1927. 29-3m.

full articles.headline: ORDINANCE.
full articles.article:
AN ORDlNA ANCE for the regulation OF the own


eIs riders, and drivers of carriages, wagons,


carts, drays, and horses, within the Borough OF


Wilmington.


SEC /. BE It ordatnedby Me Burgesses and b.
rough Council Of the Borough Of lpiioington,
That from and after the passing oftbls ordinance,
all and every the drivers or driver OF all stages,
coaches. wagons, carts, drays, and other car
riages of pleasure or burthcn, driving and passing
in and through the streets, lanes, or alley OF tins
Borough, shall keep on that side Of the street,
lane or alley oil his or their right handy, respect
iyely, in the passing directions and if any driver
OF any such carriage, wagon, cart or dray, shall
drive the same III the middle of the street, lane
or alley, or on the left hand side ii the same, 50
as to prevent or obstruct another carriage from
passing along said street, every driver SO offend
ing shall forfeit and pay for every such offence,
sum not exceeding five dollarJ nor less than one
dollar, to be recovered with COSTS before either
of the iiurgesses, in the same manner as debts
under forty shllngs are by law recoverable, one
moety whereof shall be for the use of the person
suing for the same, and tie other muictv Shall be
for the use of the Borough.


SEC. . Ind be 1t further ord,Haed, That if
any driver Of any such carriage, or If any person
riding upon any horse, mare or geiding, shall per
INIT suffer the beast or beasts he shall so drive
| or ride, to so in gallop or other immoderate
gait, or shall engage in running or racing in any
manner, with the driver rider of any other car
riage, horse, mare or geldng, within any of the
streets, lanes or alleys Of tins Borough, every
person offending, shall forfeit and pay for eve
ry such offence, sum not exceeding Five dol
lars nor less than one dollar, to be recovered
with costs, by any person, in the manner and IL,
the uses herein before mentioned.


SEC ;. Ind be L further mdaincd, That if an,
person shall wiltully permit or suffer any horse
mare or geldng TO go at large through any 0
the streets, lanes or ALLEYS, ofthis borough, ever,
person SO offending shall forfeit and pay for eve
ny such offence, the sum Of one dollar, to be re
covered with costs, by any person, in the man
ner and for the uses herein before mentioned.
SEC. 4. Ind be II further oedaiaea, That TIL
e Ordinance entitled can Ordinance to prevcn
the accidents and dangers that may happen b
peoples driving their teams out Of walk taste
than is herein specified, and persons playing a
long bullets or any other game whereby thcr
may be damage sustained" passed on the thirty
first day of August in the year Of our LORD on
: thousand seven hundred and tifty-onc, be, an
the same thereby repealed, made null and void
: Passed at the Town lIall--April Z, 1927.
JAMES BR0BSoN, First Burgess.


(AttesD j. T. FAIHLAMn,


Chrk gfMe Borough C0tnacH

full articles.headline: From tbs National Inteiligencer.
full articles.article:
To THE EDIToRs.-In the Intelligencer
ct this morning, read an account OF the loss
Of number of sheep about Waterville, in
the State of New-York, which as stated, was
occasioned by the grub worm making its
Judgement above the eye of sheep. and that
no means as yet had been discovered for its
destruction.


Sheep being esteemed valuable stock,
anc the growers of wool valuable class Of
citizens, disease so destructive to that use
full animal is worthy of notice; and as deem
it duty incumbent upon every citizen to
furnish such information, when in his pos
session, as may conduce to the public good,
for the benefit of those interested, will
state what know to be a fact. The oil q
amber which may be had at most OF the a.
pothecary shops, will instantly dislodge all
worms, maggots, &c. 1t may be applied by
dipping feather into the amber, and gently
stroking the parts affected. This remedy
has proved effectual when every other ap-
plication has been used in vain. Should this
remedy succeed with sheep, as when appli-
ed to all other animals, it will be a source OF
much qualification to--yours, respectfully


GEO. JOHNSON.


-4tTii 13, 1927.

full articles.headline: PHYSICKING POULTRY.
full articles.article:
FH SlChlNG FoOL ny.


During the winter months, poultry Of all
kinds, if tolerably fed, are apt to become We
ry fat; and it is during this period that eggs
are scarcest, and OF course dearest.-To
remedy this in some measure, several farm
ers' wives in this neighborhood, are actually
in the habit of physicing their chuckies and
the practice is said to have wonderful ct
feet in restoring their suspended laying pow
ers. The recipe is exceedingly cheap and
simple, and may be recorded here for the
benefit of hem wives in other quarters. Di-
Lutte and mix two ounces of glauber salts in
dish of cold porridge, or any other food,
and scatter the same we'll aboutthe poultry
yard, SO that no bird may eat too much; and
afthe effects are not apparent in two or three
days, repeat the dose at intervals, till the
accumulation of eggs indicate that you have
gone far enough. On farm not many miles
from this, town, the family complained that
although they had dozens of lazy hens they
could not get single egg to breakfast. and
this circumstance reminded one of the
daughters of the necessity of having recourse
to her wanted charm. To work therefore
she set, to the great annoyance of an Eng
lish dairy-maid, who averred that also sh'
had hundreds of poultry under her charge
she never before heard of such thing, ant
shat she was sure the birds would all de-
Miss ----, however, persevered, and in tn
course of a very few days, Easther found sew
eral eggs, and from that moment declare
herself firm convert to the improved meth
cd of managing poultry.

full articles.headline: Young Ladies Boardsg School,
full articles.article:
AT WILMINGlON, DCLVARE.


Under the superintendent and etruction of
WILLIAM SHERER, assisted by aomplished
female teachers. Il


The course of instruction pursued aAis SEM
mary, comprises all the useful, and mt of the
ornamental branches of female education The
daily exercises are Orthography, Reading,Wrt-
ing, Arithmetic, English Grammar, Rh.,ric;
Geography and History, ancient and MORN,
with constant reference to the best maps nd I
charts; Construction of maps; use Of the Globt
Natural History; Natural Philosophy, ncludin,
Astronomy and Chemistry Elements Of Moral
Science.


Ueekip Exercises. biblical Recitations; Evil
dences Of Christianity, Letter Writing, and 9th.
er species of Compositions Recapitulatlons,


1,rms-Board and tuition, in any Of the tori;
going branches, s32, so per quarter; or, If palo
in advance, $50, Music, including the use OF
piano, s12, French, by one of the best masters,
Sc per quarter. Moderate extra charges foi
Drawing and other ornamental branches.


The discipline of tho school is mild, parental
and christian Particular attention is paid mol
only to the manners Of the young ladies, but tt
their moral md religious instruction. They arc
regularly conducted to such places OF worship
and Sunday Schools, as their parents and guar
dians approve. Exercise and recreation, being
esSehtli 10 ule Preservaeioh vi heai.n anu
mental energy, occupy the intervals Of time no
devoted to study. The institution, III all its de
partmcnts, is conducted in a manner which !
is hoped, will meet the entire appreciation OF it
patrons.


References, IPilntneton-lley +. w. Gil
bert; Hon. w Hall, Hon. Louis NJ Lane: PhiLa
dephia--Rev DIR. Wilson's Rev. DR. Janeway
Mr.. William Janvicr Merchant, James 6
Thompson, Esq. Professor of Languages, Uni
Yersty Of Penns, lyania.

full articles.headline:
THE FARMER,

GARDENING.
full articles.article:
Red Petter.-It should be transplanted
into beds, where it is togrow, the last week
in May, 1t should be put in rows, two feet
apart, and the plants sixteen inches from
each other, in good rich garden mould, well
mellowed. The plants should be prepared
for transplanting by sowing the seed in hot
bed, placed in a small box, and covering it
one fourth of an inch deep, about the last
week in April. This hot bed is made by
laying twelve inches of new horse dung in
the bottom of the box, and covering it with
six inches of good garden mould. II any
freezing or very cold weather should hap
pen after the plants come up, let the box be
covered with board until the weather
changes.


1t should be hoed as often, and in the
same manner as cabbage. The pods or
capsules must be picked off and strung up in
a garnet, or other dry room, about the last
of September, or, at any rate, before the tall
frosts.


Savo,y.-It should be sowed about the
first of May, in rows eighteen inches apart,
and treated nearly like onions. Hyssop and
thyme may be treated In the same manner


Sare-It should be sowed in a small bed,
the first day Of MAY, and be transplanted
where it is to grow, when the plants are one
year old The ground should be somewhat





dry, and well manured.


Oyster Plant-The salsafy, or oyster
plant, is vegetable of easy production. and
universally eaten, when introduced to the
table. 1t resembles small parsnip in its
appearance. 1t is raised annually from
seeds, requiring no more care than the car
rot. 1t bears a tolerablc crop In Europe
it is eaten both boiled and fried. In this
country it is parboiled, and then fried either
in butter or without. In its taste, It SC
strongly resembles the oyster, that wher
sliced, and fried in butter, it can scarcely b'
distinguished from it. II is in eating iron
November to May. Like the parsnip it viii
stand out the whole winter


Cress.--Cress, or Pepper Grass, is yer,
good in salads along with lecture and white
mustard. 1t should be sown in drills, prett,
thick (as should the white mustard) and Gu
young A small quantity, IN the salad
son, should be sown every ten days, ant
slightly covered.
